label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, November 4, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding her homesickness and wishes to join him in Hawaii, her social activities in London, England, and discussing the progress of the war. Gertrude continues in her letter to discuss selling Medway Plantation after the war and living elsewhere.

metadata.label: Transcript

M 11 8 43
R 12 8
27
Nov 4th
Dear Sidney,
This morning I received,your no. 51, and an unumbered one
written Oct 8th. To date you have received nothing from me from here.
I was fascinated by both your letters,as more and more
your love of that island life increases. I can remember so well your
telling me you would never want to live in the tropics,as that life,
air,and soft climate demoralized one. It killed am[b]ition, energy, and
all ones will. I can remember always how you have felt about places
like Antibes with its carefree life,"birds of a feather flock together"
group of degenerates, and happy sinners. I remember your telling me
how one loses ones satndards, ones sense of right and wrong, and just
get soft and go to pieces. I am anxious to know whether you have
noticed yourself slipping, or whether your job is sufficient to keep
you on yourtoes. Whether climate has really nothing to do with it
at all, whether it is a matter of having work to do which prevents
one from sliding,and disintergrating. I wonder[whether]the Antibes atmostphere
prevails, whether casual sinning is also part of the picture.
Personally I have always loved the tropics, loved that soft
air, loved the beauty of it all, everything about it. To be in that
climate under those palm[s,] near that sea with YOU- to me would be all
that I could ask for, all that I could want. I would be happy there
forever.I just hope we do go there together when this is over[,]and that
you will show me all the beauty, and every ince of the parts you love
most. I hope when you are there in that moonlight and sunset that you
do think of me - and miss me,and do not makeshift with some one else.
The romantic setting must be tough to take alone,and I often wonder
whether as one so often hears'the tropics will get you'. I somehow feel
nothing on earth can change a person- they are what they are regardless
of any local setting. A setting is only a good excuse. I for example
am surrounded by lonely american men, everyone of them homesick, but
I assure you I only want one man and thats you. I am homesick for you
in Hawaii. I'm not homesick in the least for Americ_a. I would n't
care if I never went home for years if I got to you . Where I am makes
little difference. The bottom fell out of my life when you left, and
the only way it will ever be meanded is when I get you back. I hope
you feel as I do, and then when the war is over we will spend many
happy years again together. You are so far away, I feel so out of touch
-its discourraging. It takes six weeks to get a letter[,]and I wonder
about you so much, so many things. You never mention your back any more.
I wonder if that too has straightened itself out and you no longer
suffer from it.
I am so sorry to hear Morris has been feeling badly.
It is funny how people do not learn their limitations. After living
withone self for for[ty]two years you would think he would learn better
how to take care of himself, know when to stop, to rest, and not
wear onself into a standstill where one has to end up in bed and be
[End Page 1]
2
out of the office completely for several days. I am so glad darling
that you are beginning to catch on, to realize that it is far betterNOT
to go back to the office on Sunday other wish you may be no good for
several days. I am as strong as a horse but I too know that if I dont
get eight hours sleep of a night I just am cokked next day. I am
always in bed at 11.or at most 11.30 Once since I have been here I
have gone dancing- gone to a night club.It was with Raymond Guest the
other night and I got home at 12.45 and was so tired next day I thought
I would die. Incidently he caught a cold and did n't even show up next
day. He was in bed with a feaver. It was fun though. First I had given
my landlady Mrs Farley a cocktail party at her flat with my liquor.
There were about 20 of us. She invited her freinds mostly women, old
horrors, russian refugee group and what not. I produced themen from
the office. It was great fun, and at about 8 o'clock Raymond who was
the last to go asled me to come and have dinner with him. We went to
Wiltons where oysters are a specialty and we had a delicious bottle
of white wine, turtle soup, and a crab salad. Then we walked[for onever
finds a taxi at night] to the 400 Club. It was at that point not open
yet for business, so we sat on a park bench just opposite and watche
the search lights streak across the skye wheile he explained the solar
system to me and pointed out his great nautical knowledge of the sttrs.
We laughed a good deal and finally got in,the first people on the floor.
The music is excellent so we twirled about, around and around and I did
enjoy dancing again. I have N't danced for so long I thought I would
have forgotten how. I guess I was rusty too. Then at midnight we started
walking home. We walked and we walked, he did not know his streeets any
better than me and we must have walked three miles at least. I was quite
histerical- it was so funny wandering about, tripping over the curbs
and having to ask everyone wheich way to turn. However as this was the
only bit of air I had had for days I quite enjoyed it.
Last night I dined with Lou's right hand man- called Wyker or
Weykoff -I dont know what his name was, Lady Brownlow and Stewrt Mc Clintc
ic. We dined at Quaglinos which was delicious and were home by 11 P.M.
A delightful evening. There are some very nice people about and I have
met quite a few new faces. Mostly air corps people who are most interestig
on their subject. Rod Tower blew in today, and everyday there is a new
old face that crops up.
I had a funny thing happen at lunch yesterday. I was invited
by a girl called Polly Peabody.to lunch in her house on a,muse tucked
away over miles from here. I arrived along with three other invited
guests to find Polly had thought she had invited us all for the follwing
day. She was most embarrassed and as no one had any intentions of leaving
we said we were going to raid the kitchen. Well you know what it is these
days with coupons.Food just does not come easy, but fortunately she had
phesant some onehad given her so we went to town on that with a green
salad thrown in and although we all were out for much more than our usual
alotted hour for lunch- we had fun. It was a sweet tiny little house
made from an old converted stable. She had a big fire going and we ate
atone end of the living room. An englishman who is a big shot in the
Government was there and was terribly interesting about politics, war
etc. I enjoyed it enormously. He had just returned from the U.S. and
felt the Republicans were going to be hard to beat in the next elections.
[End Page 2]
3
I see that more pay has been granted our strikers- which to me is a depressing
picture. They ceratinly are pampered.
The Pacific war always sounds as though it was going favorably, but
I am sure as you once said- their are plenty of losses on our side too which
is never mentioned much in the papers.
The Russians are well underway in this side of the Atlantic and I
think its wonderful. Ofcourse the real tough fighting lies ahead of us. We
are all set now to really go into the fray in a big way and it is boung to
be costly I should think. I think lots of people are hopeful that next spring
will be the clean up and I hope they are right.
I mailed you and Morris to-day a little Xmas present from our old
freind"LongmanStrong'in the Arm" -  do you remember the shop? They are two
tie clips one for you and one for Morris. If you cant wear them with your uniform
you can use them to clip papers together with. They bring you my love and best
wishes for Xmas and the wish thatsome day we may all shoot pheasants together
again and walk across fields with spanials at our heels.
I hope my letters are starting to arrive. My no I was from the [removed my censor]
in [removed my censor]
all the rest here.
I have missed everything between your 45 and your 51. I hope they
turn up. I am very careful never to mention the place I am in wheich also
applies to you when you write to me. Watchout for that or else the sencor w
will hold up the letter and I may never get it at all.
I hope by now you have the A.P.O. no. all straight and will write
me to that as you are supposed to.
You asked me about Butterworth. Yes he was in our Embassy there.I
have forgotten his title. Alice Enos was the wife of the acting British Minister
when I was there She is married as you know to Hopkinson who is very nice endeed
- and I wrote ou I had dinner with him on his terrace overlooking the view
of the river.
I thought what a great idead that was about plowing up the Medway road.
I never would have thought of it. Very clever of you Pal. That ought to stop
them. I agree over and over with you that Medway is not the place for us. We
'll sell it when we get hom and go live in the sunshine, or on a little farm
in the north. I know we'll find a better life, a simpler one with less worries.
First I want to think of nothing but going to some perfect spot with you- and
no thought of anything. My how I want that. After a winter of darkness, fog,
dampness, no sunshine and shoddy streets believe me I shall be so longing for
clean clear blue and white, sea, skye and above all sun. The fog gets in your
throat and sticks, and this fog is nothing to what is ahead I am told.
Well darling I am glad I am here and not Washington, glad I can hear
a real siren that means something once in a while, glad I can do a job closer
to the front. Its a better atmosphere than Washington I assure you, much better.
Everyone is working, working hard, the people are magnificsent and they talk
of the Esprit de corps of those big Blitz days with sort of reverence, emotion,
and feelings,with great humourthrown in that are no longer obvious today,as
people now have security once more.
I must stop [and] do some work that has just come in - Goodbye darling -
All my love - Gertie.
[End Page 3]
